Learn Maths With Alice Lingyun Zhang 2019-01-05 Preface Like other parents, I want to help my children (Alan and Alice) learn maths well. Fortunately, I qualify for this job—I was good at maths when I was a student and I earned a PhD in Mathematical Statistics at age 30. To help my children, especially Alice, I prepare the learning materials, and these materials form the current book. This book covers Year 1 to Year 13 school maths. There are three main parts. Part I is about Arithmetic. Part II comprises Algebra, Geometry (including Coordinate Geometry) and Trigonometric. Part III contains Elementary Calculus. For sure, this book is useful for my tasks helping my children, and I hope it will also be useful for you as parents helping your children learn maths. So, the intended audience of this book are those parents and their children.
Part II: Algebra, Geometry and Trigonometric 0.2 Solving equations with two unknowns

Part II: Algebra, Geometry and Trigonometric 0.2 Solving equations with two unknowns Let’s try to solve the this problem: Alan thought two numbers and he asked Alice to guess what they are. Alan told Alice that the sum of the two numbers are 100 and the difference between the two numbers is 36. Can you help Alice figure out the two numbers? Analysis: We must find the two numbers, which are unknowns to us. So, why not let the two unknowns be \(x\) and \(y\). Immediately, we have the following two equations \[ \left\{ \begin{array}{ccl} x + y &=& 100\\ x - y &=& 36 \end{array} \right. \] Now, if we can solve the two equations then we solve the problem. This chapter is about solving equations with two unknowns. By that, I mean we want to find \(x\) and \(y\) in equations like the above one. The method for solving this type of equations are called elimination method; as the name indicates the key is that we firstly knock out one unknown and then we get the other one. For the above the problem, we can knock out \(y\) be adding the two equations together \[ 2x = 136, \] from whch easily we have \(x=\frac{136}{2}=68\). Next, to find \(y\), we can either replace 68 for \(x\) in one equation to have \(68+y=100\), which yields \(y=32\), or we this time knock out \(y\) by using the top equation to substract the second equation \[ 2y = 64, \] from which again we get \(y=32\).
